post.message: It was mostly like I was reading my own story. :D
If I was you, I'd definitely included 1944.
This was not a comprehensive list. I would definetly add it in another one for sure
Mmhmm..
Nice :)
I used to think it was said by Steve Jobs in some studio...
Beautiful and inspiring words.
It is a quote usedby apple for adverts
Really good stuff. Often, a lot of people consider designing inferior. But it turns out to be a crucial part. Great work !
That's very creative work.üòã
Finally something I can recommend to people starting out and wants to make their site sleek.
f4animesh more
I love how there are so many options, and we care about finding just the write one for us. Kudos! Keep making notes :)

Beautiful lines.
It is not just story of two pens or two friends, but of the four people we had surrounded ourselves with in this society.
Four as in? I get the two friends, and the teacher. Who is the fourth?

Four people full of greed, fear, ego and jealousy from whom we seeks affirmation.
sbse bada rog, Kya kahenge char log !
üëèüëèüëè

I agree that these books are lengthy and consume a lot of time to read. But for someone looking for months of endearing fantasy, these are an easy recommendation. If you ever find yourself to be trapped by the never ending narrative, just finish the book, you will find yourself immersed in the next book before you know.

So, summers mein chill rahega, if I want to read? I mean are the books independent or they leave with a cliffhanger?
They are complete books but they have a over-arching storyline which can be enjoyed only if you read all of them in serial order.

In others when I am wrong,
And in myself when others have wronged.

How to know when which one of those two happens? I have also encoounter this but do not know how to face it.
Okay so overall why would you recommend to someone who is not much into fantasy setting and stuff like that?

The problem here is that no one knows if the seeds they plant would give fruit. Only when the time has passed and the weather has been kind will the person know if the plant blossoms with bountiful fruits or is just another weed with thorns.

Only time will tell.

Only time will tell.

Sad but true.
Boy, this post looks as elegant as your posters!
I did almost the same path, but I ended with Ulysses on Desktop, Moon Writer on Android, and sync using Dropbox with DropSync app. Works like a charm and no script needed.

Thanks, I didn't know about Dropsync, and Moon Writer.
I will surely try them out!

Cool, you're welcome! Moon Writer is just a stand-alone multi-folder-handler md-editor for Android, nothing else. The trick is around Dropsync, which can be set to map and auto-sync a local folder to a Dropbox directory. Syncing from Dropbox folder to Desktop is handled by Ulysses by-design, but, as we are talking about Dropbox, any local editor could be used for managing your notes on Desktop.
Which hackathon did you participate in? Link for the product?

Hackinout
hackinout.co

The registration for the domain is at go.co/HackInOut

Hey all, InOut organizer here. Here's the response from Nettigritty about the matter. We advise to directly get in touch with Nettigritty for any queries regarding their offerings.
https://uploads.disquscdn.c...
Never knew that there's so much more to choosing a simple font...

On Android (which now includes Chromebooks) I use Termux and git to sync my notes repo and Markor for editing.

In Termux, you can share a folder with the system, so Markor can open the file directly. I use the Termux widget to sync.
Yes I would recommend it, specially now during the pandemic!
I understand your point now. What a comeback even if it took a year.
"Your comeback should be stronger than the setback" - A random quote from r/GetMotivated

Yes but at what cost?
You had a comeback at the cost of the world going down!

What's down What's Up?
Everything is relative!
What a statement!
Awesome
https://media3.giphy.com/me...
Amazing covers! The Farmhouse one looks absolutely professional!

Corona X16 would be my favourite ‚ù§Ô∏è

Also, please enable guest comment posting.
I like it! Thank you for your sharing. I also take notes between pc and laptop, sync is very important.
Lovely website! I look forward to reading more of your material.
Good one
Noice. I switched from Manjaro i3 to Arch just to try it out but Manjaro definitely is very comfortable

> Embedding and a live preview with export if needed sealed the deal for me.

Why do you find the Live Preview useful? I am intrigued by some users who use the WYSISWYG editors with half the screen taken up by the live preview!!!

(Personally, I get more value from having other text that I have written for reference and idle checking on the whole screen, as much as possible and prevent duplication. So, I want to find the value in a live preview and see if there is a hole in my workflow which can be filled using a live preview)

I am curious because I am sure you have written Markdown long enough to know what it looks like and VSCode's Markdown editor does the basic formatting for blockquotes, code blocks and headings (I presume, for I have never used it).

I write and read my notes 99% of the times in plain text VSCode.

However, Live Preview comes in handy once in a while, for example, to view an embedded image. Most of the times I avoid embedding images for the reasons that you described: It is better to note down the essence, rather than make the notes a dumping ground with too much information.

But in a few rare occasions, images are convenient, and I can't open the note in Typora just to view the image. As I usually have a split pane already open, the viewer directly opens to the file at that line. Moreover, It is a simple handy shortcut Cmd+K V away.

Example of images in my notes I can't remove https://uploads.disquscdn.c...
